articles.headline: G.M. Adds Workers and Shifts as Demand Surges
articles.snippet: The changes will bring 1,350 idled union workers back to work and provide overtime shifts for about 10,000 workers.
articles.abstract: The changes will bring 1,350 idled union workers back to work and provide overtime shifts for about 10,000 workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Guess who is adding shifts and running on overtime to build more cars. General Motors.

articles.headline: H.P. Tries to Keep the Ink Flowing
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard’s printing group has been one of the company’s star performers, accounting for nearly a quarter of overall revenue, but that may be changing.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard’s printing group has been one of the company’s star performers, accounting for nearly a quarter of overall revenue, but that may be changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve heard about the fears of a jobless economic recovery. For Hewlett-Packard, there is an even darker threat looming as the world works its way out of a recession: an inkless recovery.

articles.headline: For Older Athletes, Drug Question Emerges
articles.snippet: Elderly athletes are setting records. Most are also taking several medications for their health, and that raises the question of what now constitutes a natural body.
articles.abstract: Elderly athletes are setting records. Most are also taking several medications for their health, and that raises the question of what now constitutes a natural body.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his apartment outside Philadelphia, Frank Levine pulled a list of prescription medications from his refrigerator, his hands shaking slightly. There was metformin HCl and glipizide for his diabetes; lisinopril for his blood pressure; and Viagra.

articles.headline: Oil Industry Backs Protests of Emissions Bill
articles.snippet: Companies say new policies from Washington could cost them billions of dollars and raise prices for consumers at the pump.
articles.abstract: Companies say new policies from Washington could cost them billions of dollars and raise prices for consumers at the pump.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Hard on the heels of the health care protests, another citizen movement seems to have sprung up, this one to oppose Washington’s attempts to tackle climate change. But behind the scenes, an industry with much at stake  Big Oil  is pulling the strings.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: F.B.I. Agents’ Role Is Transformed by Terror Fight
articles.snippet: Some counterterrorism specialists question the value of threat squads that vet thousands of tips but find few leads.
articles.abstract: Some counterterrorism specialists question the value of threat squads that vet thousands of tips but find few leads.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORWALK, Calif.  The report last month was chilling: a 55-gallon drum of radioactive material had gone missing during shipment from North Carolina to California. Even worse, the person who signed for the cargo was not an employee of the company that ordered the load.

articles.headline: Judges Overturn Backdating Conviction
articles.snippet: Citing misconduct by prosecutors, a federal appeals court overturned the conviction of the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems.
articles.abstract: Citing misconduct by prosecutors, a federal appeals court overturned the conviction of the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citing misconduct by prosecutors, a federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned the conviction of the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems on charges related to the illegal backdating of stock options.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In Appraisal Shift, Lenders Gain Power and Critics
articles.snippet: A change meant to curb conflicts of interest may have opened new problems in the real estate industry.
articles.abstract: A change meant to curb conflicts of interest may have opened new problems in the real estate industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mike Kennedy, a real estate appraiser in Monroe, N.Y., was examining a suburban house a few years ago when he discovered five feet of water in the basement. The mortgage broker arranging the owner’s refinancing asked him to pretend it was not there.

articles.headline: Senator Moves to Block Medical Ghostwriting
articles.snippet: Pressure from Washington may force changes in drug companies’ involvement with research papers.
articles.abstract: Pressure from Washington may force changes in drug companies’ involvement with research papers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A growing body of evidence suggests that doctors at some of the nation’s top medical schools have been attaching their names and lending their reputations to scientific papers that were drafted by ghostwriters working for drug companies  articles that were carefully calibrated to help the manufacturers sell more products.

articles.headline: A Conservative’s Road to Same-Sex Marriage Advocacy
articles.snippet: Theodore B. Olson’s decision to file a lawsuit challenging California’s ban on gay marriage has stirred up suspicion on both sides.
articles.abstract: Theodore B. Olson’s decision to file a lawsuit challenging California’s ban on gay marriage has stirred up suspicion on both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: Theodore B. Olson’s office is a testament to his iconic status in the conservative legal movement. A framed photograph of Ronald Reagan, the first of two Republican presidents Mr. Olson served, is warmly inscribed with “heartfelt thanks.” Fifty-five white quills commemorate each of his appearances before the Supreme Court, where he most famously argued the 2000 election case that put George W. Bush in the White House. On the bookshelf sits a Defense Department medal honoring his legal defense of Mr. Bush’s counterterrorism policies after Sept. 11.

articles.headline: 2 Blasts Expose Security Flaws in Heart of Iraq
articles.snippet: Insurgents struck at the heart of Iraq’s government, killing at least 95 people in the worst attacks since U.S. forces handed over security responsibilities in June.
articles.abstract: Insurgents struck at the heart of Iraq’s government, killing at least 95 people in the worst attacks since U.S. forces handed over security responsibilities in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Insurgents struck at the heart of the Iraqi government on Wednesday in two huge and deadly bombings that exposed a new vulnerability after Americans ceded control for security here on June 30. Nearby American soldiers stood by helplessly  despite the needs of hundreds of wounded lying among the dead  waiting for a request for assistance from Iraqi officials that apparently never came.

articles.headline: Key Index in China Falls on Fear of a Bubble
articles.snippet: Investors worry that an asset bubble may be forming in China, fueled in part by a $586 billion economic stimulus package.
articles.abstract: Investors worry that an asset bubble may be forming in China, fueled in part by a $586 billion economic stimulus package.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the United States lurches toward recovery, many investors are looking to China to help lift the global economy and stoke financial markets.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Bettina Wassener

articles.headline: Names Deal Cracks Swiss Bank Secrecy
articles.snippet: U.S. regulators will receive the names as part of an investigation of Americans avoiding taxes through the use of offshore accounts.
articles.abstract: U.S. regulators will receive the names as part of an investigation of Americans avoiding taxes through the use of offshore accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the latest setback to Switzerland’s tradition of banking secrecy, UBS, one of the nation’s largest banks, agreed on Wednesday to turn over information on more than 4,400 American clients suspected by the Internal Revenue Service of using Swiss accounts for tax evasion.
